# Aquatic respiration

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Pleurobranchaea_meckelii.jpg/300px-
Pleurobranchaea_meckelii.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pleurobranchaea_meckelii.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pleurobranchaea_meckelii.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sea slugs](/wiki/Sea_slug "Sea slug") breathe through a gill (or ctenidium)

**Aquatic respiration** is the [process](/wiki/Biological_process "Biological
process") whereby an [aquatic animal](/wiki/Aquatic_animal "Aquatic animal")
obtains [oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") from [water](/wiki/Water "Water").

## Respiratory
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Respiratory systems")]

### Fish[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Fish")]

See also: [Fish respiration](/wiki/Fish_respiration "Fish respiration")

In most fish respiration takes place through
[gills](/wiki/Gills_\(biology\)#Vertebrate_gills "Gills \(biology\)").
[Lungfish](/wiki/Lungfish "Lungfish"), however, possess one or two lungs. The
[labyrinth fish](/wiki/Anabantoidei "Anabantoidei") have developed a special
organ that allows them to take advantage of the oxygen of the air, but is not
a true lung. Fish use the process known as countercurrent flow, in which water
and blood flow in opposite directions across the gills, maximizing the
diffusion of oxygen.

###
Molluscs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Molluscs")]

See also: [Respiratory system of
gastropods](/wiki/Respiratory_system_of_gastropods "Respiratory system of
gastropods")

[Molluscs](/wiki/Molluscs "Molluscs") generally possess gills that allow
exchange of oxygen from an aqueous environment into the circulatory system.
These animals also possess a heart that pumps blood which contains
hemocyaninine as its oxygen-capturing molecule. Therefore, this respiratory
system is similar to that of vertebrate fish. The [respiratory system of
gastropods](/wiki/Respiratory_system_of_gastropods "Respiratory system of
gastropods") can include either gills or a lung.

###
Arthropods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Arthropods")]

See also: [Gill § Invertebrate gills](/wiki/Gill#Invertebrate_gills "Gill")

Aquatic [arthropods](/wiki/Arthropod "Arthropod") generally possess some form
of gills in which gas exchange takes place by diffusing through the
[exoskeleton](/wiki/Exoskeleton "Exoskeleton"). Others may breathe atmospheric
air while remaining submerged, via breathing tubes or trapped air bubbles,
though some [aquatic insects](/wiki/Aquatic_insect "Aquatic insect") may
remain submerged indefinitely and respire using a
[plastron](/wiki/Plastron_\(arthropod\) "Plastron \(arthropod\)"). A very few
[Arachnids](/wiki/Arachnid "Arachnid") have adopted an aquatic life style
including the [Diving bell spider](/wiki/Diving_bell_spider "Diving bell
spider"). In all cases, oxygen is provided from air trapped by hairs around
the animals body.

### Aquatic
reptiles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Aquatic reptiles")]

All aquatic reptiles breathe air into lungs. The [anatomical
structure](/wiki/Anatomy "Anatomy") of the [lungs](/wiki/Lungs "Lungs") is
less complex in [reptiles](/wiki/Reptiles "Reptiles") than in
[mammals](/wiki/Mammals "Mammals"), with reptiles lacking the very extensive
airway tree structure found in mammalian lungs. [Gas
exchange](/wiki/Gas_exchange "Gas exchange") in reptiles still occurs in
[alveoli](/wiki/Alveoli "Alveoli") however, reptiles do not possess a
[diaphragm](/wiki/Thoracic_diaphragm "Thoracic diaphragm"). Thus, breathing
occurs via a change in the volume of the body cavity which is controlled by
contraction of [intercostal muscles](/wiki/Intercostal_muscle "Intercostal
muscle") in all reptiles except [turtles](/wiki/Turtle "Turtle"). In turtles,
contraction of specific pairs of flank muscles governs
[inspiration](/wiki/Inhalation "Inhalation") or [expiration](/wiki/Exhalation
"Exhalation").[1]

See also [reptiles](/wiki/Reptiles#Respiration "Reptiles") for more detailed
descriptions of the respiratory system in these animals.

###
Amphibians[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Amphibians")]

See also: [Amphibian § Respiratory system](/wiki/Amphibian#Respiratory_system
"Amphibian")

Both the lungs and the [skin](/wiki/Frog#Morphology_and_physiology "Frog")
serve as respiratory organs in [amphibians](/wiki/Amphibians "Amphibians").
The skin of these animals is highly vascularized and moist, with moisture
maintained via secretion of [mucus](/wiki/Mucus "Mucus") from specialized
cells. While the lungs are of primary importance to breathing control, the
skin's unique properties aid rapid gas exchange when amphibians are submerged
in oxygen-rich water.[2]

### Aquatic
birds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Aquatic birds")]

The respiratory system of birds differs significantly from that found in
mammals, containing unique anatomical features such as [air
sacs](/wiki/Air_sacs "Air sacs"). The lungs of birds also do not have the
capacity to inflate as birds lack a [diaphragm](/wiki/Thoracic_diaphragm
"Thoracic diaphragm") and a [pleural cavity](/wiki/Pleural_cavity "Pleural
cavity"). Gas exchange in birds occurs between air capillaries and [blood
capillaries](/wiki/Capillary "Capillary"), rather than in
[alveoli](/wiki/Alveoli "Alveoli"). See [Avian respiratory
system](/wiki/Bird_anatomy#Respiratory_system "Bird anatomy") for a detailed
description of these and other features.

## Gills[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Gills")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Tuna_Gills_in_Situ_01.jpg/220px-
Tuna_Gills_in_Situ_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tuna_Gills_in_Situ_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tuna_Gills_in_Situ_01.jpg "Enlarge")

Posterior view of the gills of a [tuna](/wiki/Tuna "Tuna")

Large aquatic animals have developed [gills](/wiki/Gill "Gill") for
[respiration](/wiki/Respiration_\(physiology\) "Respiration \(physiology\)")
which are specifically adapted to their function, for example, they have:

  * A large [surface area](/wiki/Surface_area "Surface area") to allow as much [oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") to enter the gills as possible because more of the gas comes into contact with the [membrane](/wiki/Biological_membrane "Biological membrane")
  * Good [blood supply](/wiki/Blood_circulation "Blood circulation") to maintain the concentration gradient needed
  * Thin membrane to allow for a short diffusion pathway
  * each gill arch has two rows (hemibranchs) of [gill filaments](/wiki/Gill_filament "Gill filament")
  * each gill filament has many [lamellae](/wiki/Lamella_\(zoology\) "Lamella \(zoology\)")

In [osteichthyes](/wiki/Osteichthyes "Osteichthyes"), the gills contain 4
[gill arches](/wiki/Gill_arch "Gill arch") on each side of the head, two on
each side for [chondrichthyes](/wiki/Chondrichthyes "Chondrichthyes") or 7
gill baskets on each side of the fish's head in [Lampreys](/wiki/Lampreys
"Lampreys"). In fish, the long bony cover for the gill (the
[operculum](/wiki/Operculum_\(fish\) "Operculum \(fish\)")) can be used for
pushing water. Some fish pump water using the operculum. Without an operculum,
other methods, such as ram [ventilation](/wiki/Ventilation_\(physiology\)
"Ventilation \(physiology\)"), are required. Some species of
[sharks](/wiki/Shark "Shark") use this system. When they swim, water flows
into the mouth and across the gills. Because these sharks rely on this
technique, they must keep swimming in order to respire.

Bony fish use [countercurrent flow](/wiki/Countercurrent_exchange
"Countercurrent exchange") to maximize the intake of oxygen that can
[diffuse](/wiki/Diffusion "Diffusion") through the gill. Countercurrent flow
occurs when deoxygenated blood moves through the gill in one direction while
oxygenated water moves through the gill in the opposite direction. This
mechanism maintains the [concentration gradient](/wiki/Concentration_gradient
"Concentration gradient") thus increasing the efficiency of the respiration
process as well and prevents the oxygen levels from reaching an
[equilibrium](/wiki/Chemical_equilibrium "Chemical equilibrium").
Cartilaginous fish do not have a countercurrent flow system as they lack bones
which are needed to have the opened out gill that bony fish have.

## Control of
respiration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aquatic_respiration&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Control of respiration")]

Scientists have investigated what part of the body is responsible for
maintaining the respiratory rhythm. They found that [neurons](/wiki/Neuron
"Neuron") located in the [brainstem](/wiki/Brainstem "Brainstem") of fish are
responsible for the genesis of the respiratory rhythm.[3] The position of
these neurons is slightly different from the centers of respiratory genesis in
mammals but they are located in the same brain compartment, which has caused
debates about the [homology](/wiki/Homology_\(biology\) "Homology
\(biology\)") of respiratory centers between aquatic and terrestrial species.
In both aquatic and terrestrial respiration, the exact mechanisms by which
neurons can generate this involuntary rhythm are still not completely
understood (see [Involuntary control of
respiration](/wiki/Involuntary_control_of_respiration "Involuntary control of
respiration")).

Another important feature of the respiratory rhythm is that it is modulated to
adapt to the oxygen consumption of the body. As observed in mammals, fish
“breathe” faster and heavier when they do [physical exercise](/wiki/Exercise
"Exercise"). The mechanisms by which these changes occur have been strongly
debated over more than 100 years between scientists.[4] The authors can be
classified in 2 schools:

1\. Those who think that the major part of the respiratory changes are pre-
programmed in the brain, which would imply that neurons from
[locomotion](/wiki/Animal_locomotion "Animal locomotion") centers of the brain
connect to [respiratory centers](/wiki/Respiratory_center "Respiratory
center") in anticipation of movements.

2\. Those who think that the major part of the respiratory changes result from
the detection of muscle contraction, and that respiration is adapted as a
consequence of muscular contraction and oxygen consumption. This would imply
that the brain possesses some kind of detection mechanisms that would trigger
a respiratory response when muscular contraction occurs.

Many now agree that both mechanisms are probably present and complementary, or
working alongside a mechanism that can detect changes in oxygen and/or carbon
dioxide blood saturation.
